description: DNS query to youtu.be marked as high entropy, which can indicate use of DNS tunneling to exfiltrate data or maintain C2 channels.
Forwarded high-entropy DNS request to youtu.be, matching known public DNS servers. While high entropy is suspicious, youtu.be is a legitimate domain.
Query to high-entropy domain youtu.be from internal IP address. Though flagged for entropy, this domain is widely used and benign.
Forwarded DNS request for high-entropy domain to another internal resolver. Benign domain usage makes attack unlikely despite entropy alert.
Reply to high-entropy DNS domain, confirming resolution. Shows no direct signs of abuse; youtu.be is a legitimate video hosting domain.
Another resolver provides legitimate IP reply to youtu.be query. Repetition adds no evidence of malicious behavior.
Detected unusual frequency drop in DNS 'A' record queries. Might indicate system inactivity, misconfiguration, or stealthy scanning patterns.
New IMAP login event pattern: disconnected with no authentication. Might indicate reconnaissance or automated login attempts testing service response.
Same IMAP login anomaly reported in different log source. Confirms unusual behavior but not conclusively malicious alone.
Repeated anomaly of IMAP disconnect with no auth attempt from same IP. Persistence across logs strengthens case for abnormal probing behavior.
No host name found for IP 192.168.130.77; could indicate reverse DNS scan or reconnaissance probe.
Repeated alert: No host name found for IP 192.168.130.77; same source implies persistence or repeated probing.
Client 192.168.130.77 denied by Apache server; accessing /var/www/html/ suggests probing or misconfiguration testing.
Client 172.17.130.196 denied by Apache; same behavior as previous line, indicating distributed scanning.
Repeated no hostname resolution for IP 192.168.130.77; consistent with network mapping.
TLS error from 192.168.130.77 during handshake; could indicate protocol misuse or downgrade attempt.
Further no hostname found for same IP; confirms repeated reverse DNS scanning or stealthy enumeration.
GET request to /nmaplowercheck with Nmap user-agent; classic sign of Nmap NSE scanning.
POST to /sdk using Nmap NSE engine from 172.17.130.196; indicates active probing of potentially exploitable services.
Basic GET / request with HTTP/1.0 and 403 status, possibly from custom or malformed scanner.
The user agent indicates the use of the Nmap Scripting Engine, often used in reconnaissance to identify services and vulnerabilities. The 403 response suggests scanning was blocked or unauthorized.
Same Nmap Scripting Engine user agent as in the previous log; the 403 code shows access was denied, further confirming a scanning attempt.
Attempt to access '/HNAP1', a known vulnerable path often targeted in IoT device exploits (e.g., D-Link routers), blocked by server configuration.
Repeated access attempt to '/HNAP1' endpoint from another port/source, suggesting a distributed or iterative attack pattern.
Access attempt to '/HNAP1' by another IP, showing coordinated or repeated probing of a known vulnerable service.
Access attempt to root web directory, possibly to check directory listings or to enumerate available endpoints. Blocked by server config.
Similar root web directory access attempt from different source; indicates scanning or fuzzing for exposed web content.
WPScan is explicitly identified in the user agent, scanning for known WordPress plugin vulnerabilities (akismet). Access was denied (403).
HEAD request targeting WordPress plugin path (analytics-for-wp); WPScan user agent confirms reconnaissance behavior.
Another HEAD request to a plugin path (animate-it); part of plugin enumeration phase in WPScan scanning.
Use of WPScan targeting a specific WordPress plugin path using the uncommon HEAD method suggests plugin enumeration.
HEAD request to another plugin directory using WPScan indicates ongoing enumeration of installed plugins.
HEAD method used by WPScan to probe plugin 'post-snippets' implies enumeration of vulnerable components.
Request pattern is consistent with plugin enumeration aimed at finding vulnerabilities in WordPress extensions.
The 'post-type-switcher' plugin path is being probed by WPScan; indicative of targeted enumeration.
HEAD method probing for the 'postmark-approved-wordpress-plugin' shows a pattern of plugin scanning.
Scan for 'postie' plugin using HEAD request continues the sequence of automated plugin enumeration.
Attempt to access 'timthumb.php' hints at checking for known vulnerable image resize script in themes.
Targeting known vulnerable script 'timthumb.php' with duplicate slashes is a common tactic to bypass filters.
Malformed access attempt to 'timthumb.phptimthumb.php' suggests misconfigured scanner or obfuscation testing.
The request uses the HEAD method targeting a known vulnerable PHP script 'timthumb.php' with a user agent identifying WPScan tool, indicating an active scan for vulnerable WordPress components.
Another HEAD request to a possibly malicious or outdated script 'thumb.php' from WPScan, indicating probing for vulnerable WordPress files.
Request attempts to access '.htpasswd', a sensitive file used for authentication; access is forbidden (403), indicating attempted unauthorized access.
Similar to the previous log, but targets a slightly altered name '.htpasswd_' to bypass filters; 403 response suggests attempted access to sensitive files.
GET request includes unusual '@' character in path, possibly fuzzing for vulnerable or misconfigured paths on the server.
Access to path containing '~adm', likely part of a scanning attempt to identify admin panels or hidden directories.
Error log shows access attempt to a suspicious script 'info.php' under WordPress directory, a common vector for reconnaissance of PHP config settings.
Use of '+' character in the request path to discover unusual file or folder names; possibly part of a fuzzing routine.
Access attempt to 'phpinfo.php', a known file used to leak server configuration info; indicates active reconnaissance for misconfigurations.
Request for '/~webmaster' suggests scanning for hidden user directories, often used in enumeration attacks.
Access to /wp-includes/js/thickbox/~www with the tilde (~) character suggests probing for backup/config or hidden files, which is typical in reconnaissance or automated vulnerability scanning.
Request failed due to lack of a directory index file; attacker could be enumerating directories to find accessible files or exploit misconfigurations.
Access to .hta file suggests probing for sensitive files or attempting to upload/execute a malicious script; access was denied by configuration.
Request to directory ending in /langs returned HTTP 301 redirect, indicating enumeration of paths possibly related to plugin language support.
Presence of '+' character in path and access to a non-existent 'lost+found' directory suggest probing for unusual or misconfigured paths.
Access to /plugins directory redirected with 301 status; attacker may be checking for plugin enumeration as part of reconnaissance.
Attempt to access 'phpinfo.php' in a typical JS directory implies testing for misconfigured PHP file locations, possibly to reveal system configuration.
Attempt to access /skins directory and being redirected implies path discovery of frontend elements, possibly to find exposed assets.
Probing /themes directory consistent with searching for known vulnerable themes or plugin-based attack vectors.
Attempt to access a missing PHP file in a theme's include directory suggests probing for vulnerable or leftover components after theme installation.
The request to a non-existent path with encoded characters ('lost+found') suggests directory enumeration or automated scanning.
Request to a suspicious PHP script ('info.php') under a theme folder indicates a probing attempt for vulnerable or misconfigured files.
Request to 'phpinfo.php' is commonly used to extract server environment info; this file is often targeted during recon scans.
Access to '/wp-includes/js/tinymce/plugins/hr/' returned 403. This path suggests probing internal plugin directories.
GET request with unusual character '~' in the path '/~logs' indicates scanning for internal or hidden directories.
Request to '/~lp' with non-standard character implies targeted path enumeration for potentially hidden resources.
Access to '/~mail' using the tilde character suggests scanning for email directories or user-based web directories.
Request to '/~nobody' implies enumeration attempts for accounts or misconfigured personal web directories.
Path '/~operator' resembles a user account directory probing attempt, possibly to find misconfigured user directories.
Request to '/info.php' in the images/admin directory of a WordPress theme suggests enumeration for sensitive admin files.
The request contains unusual characters ('+') in the URL path targeting a known WordPress theme directory, indicating potential web content enumeration or fuzzing.
Attempt to access a non-existent phpinfo.php file, which is often probed to gather system configuration and enable information disclosure.
403 Forbidden access to a directory suggests probing for sensitive content or directory traversal possibilities in a WordPress path.
Access attempt to .hta file in a WordPress directory, commonly used to hide malicious scripts or indicate probing for misconfigured hidden files.
Probing for .htpasswd file, typically used for basic HTTP auth. Indicates attempt to access sensitive credential storage files.
Access attempt to a potentially obfuscated version of .htpasswd file with underscore suffix suggests attacker is fuzzing or trying variant filenames.
Unusual character '@' in path targeting an admin folder, suggesting fuzzing or path discovery attack.
Access attempt to path with '~adm' may indicate user enumeration, as '~' is sometimes used in user home directory fuzzing.
Request for '~admin' path likely represents probing for user-specific content, a common enumeration tactic.
Denied access to .htaccess file, often a target during reconnaissance to learn web server configuration or bypass controls.
Attempt to access .htaccess file, which may contain sensitive server configuration or access control settings.
Access to .htpasswd file attempted, which may contain password hashes for basic HTTP auth; often targeted for credential harvesting.
Suspicious attempt to access a variation of .htpasswd file, indicating probing or automated scanning behavior.
Access attempt to a non-existent PHP admin file, likely probing for misconfigured or unprotected admin panels.
Attempt to access index.php in admin folder; such behavior is consistent with reconnaissance to find admin entry points.
High entropy in PHP file name and encoded parameters strongly suggests a web shell or obfuscated backdoor communication.
Continued access to suspicious PHP file with base64-encoded parameters referencing external URLs, suggesting data exfil or remote commands.
Another suspicious request to same PHP file with high-entropy query string likely used for payload execution or data exfiltration.
Unusual frequency and request patterns to a webmail endpoint from a headless browser suggest automated access or beaconing.
Abnormal CPU usage spike detected, possibly indicating mining activity, misconfiguration, or active DoS.
Unusual frequency of DNS queries from internal host (192.168.128.4) to WhatsApp CDN, possibly indicating use of DNS tunneling or beaconing to external services.
Unusual frequency of GET requests to Apache from IP 172.17.130.196, could indicate a reconnaissance scan or brute force attempt on the web server.
High entropy request to a PHP file with encoded parameters possibly indicates remote code execution or web shell activity.
Successful 'su' from web server user (www-data) to local user 'phopkins', unusual privilege escalation likely via web shell.
TTY session open for user 'phopkins' initiated by 'www-data', supporting evidence of privilege escalation activity.
Session opened for 'phopkins' by uid=33 (www-data), indicative of unauthorized access escalation from web-facing service.
Audit log shows PAM authentication success for 'phopkins' via /bin/su, potentially indicating credential compromise or session hijack.
PAM accounting success indicates continued tracking of new user activity, consistent with persistence or lateral movement.
Successful PAM setcred operation showing new credentials set for 'phopkins' by /bin/su, further confirming privilege escalation.
Session opened for 'phopkins' via /bin/su, final confirmation of a new user session post privilege escalation.
